node.text:
Dr. Moira Dillon is an Assistant Professor of Psychology at New York University and the Director of the Lab for the Developing Mind. Dr. Dillon received her B.A. from Yale University and her A.M. and Ph.D. from Harvard University. Her work has been published in top research journals including Science and the Proceedings of the National Academy of the Sciences, and she has received numerous awards for early career scholars including from the National Science Foundation, the Jacobs Foundation, and the Association for Psychological Science. Dr. Dillon’s research focuses on infant and child cognitive development, including what infants know even before they start talking, how young children use pictures and language to think more abstractly, and how parents can foster school-readiness in STEM. Dr. Dillon is also “mom" to a lovable 1-year-old!

Follow her lab @labdevelopingmindnyu for more information and advice.

In this video, Dr. Dillon answers:

1. What are the thought processes of a baby?

2. What’s the single best thing parents can do for a baby’s cognitive development? 

3.  What’s the best way to develop cognitive abilities in babies and toddlers?

4. How do I foster school readiness? 

5. What’s the best age to teach baby sign language? 

6. When does a child develop a sense of self? 

7. What are some early signs my child is inherently smart or gifted, and how do I nurture that?

#expertadvice #cognitivedevelopment #infantdevelopment #babydevelopment #braindevelopment

node.title: Infant Cognitive Development: Dr. Moira Dillon

node.text:
Melissa is a mommy of two and a speech-language pathologist specializing in babies and toddlers. Melissa's passion is teaching parents how to talk to their little ones in a way that gets them talking back! She has helped thousands of parents get their young children talking through her Raising Little Talkers online course, her beloved Instagram page of the same name, and her private practice in Los Angeles. 

Follow her at @raisinglittletalkers for more advice and information.

In this episode, Melissa answers:

1. My child is 18 months old and says at least 50 words, but doesn’t say mama. What do I do? 

2. What is the best tip for helping a 1-year-old to imitate speech and gestures? 

3. Will speaking two languages to my baby slow down their learning to speak? 

4. My 12-month-old regressed from saying “mama” to no words for 2 months. When to worry? 

5. Is it bad to use nicknames for items like “susu” for soother? 

6. Does sign language help or hinder speech and language development? 

7. What’s an appropriate age for a speech and language evaluation?

#speech #language #SLP #childdevelopment #expertadvice

node.title: Speech and Language Development: Melissa Minney, Part 1

node.text:
Jenny Best is the founder of Solid Starts (@solidstarts), a team of pediatric food + feeding experts, doctors, nutritionists, and dietitians, and the world’s first comprehensive platform for starting babies on solid food. Solid Starts features the First Foods®️ database, a free food database and app complete with instructions and how-to videos for introducing real food to babies. Solid Starts serves more than one million people from 175 countries worldwide, offering complimentary resources to those facing economic hardship. 

Follow @solidstarts for more advice and information.

In this episode, Jenny answers:

1. What is baby-led weaning (BLW)?

2. How does choking happen?

3. What are the best foods to start with?

4. How can I do baby-led weaning with food allergies?

#solidstarts #feeding #babyledweaning #blw #babydevelopment #expertadvice

node.text:
Veronica Fernandez, PhD, is a developmental psychologist and research scientist at the University of Miami. Her research focuses on understanding and improving the quality of interactions and early learning experiences for children. 

She uses inquiry and play as mechanisms to promote equity for cultural and linguistically diverse children, families, and teachers. Most importantly, she is the mommy of a curious and spunky bilingual toddler — so she is putting her research into practice every day.

Follow her at @cultivating.wonder_ for more advice and information.

In this episode, Veronica answers:

1. Is it okay to introduce a second language when neither parent is bilingual? Is it appropriative?

2. What’s the number one recommendation for encouraging a bilingual home (if you had to pick just one)?

#bilingual #multilingual #earlylearning #language #expertadvice

node.text:
Veronica Fernandez, PhD, is a developmental psychologist and research scientist at the University of Miami. Her research focuses on understanding and improving the quality of interactions and early learning experiences for children. 

She uses inquiry and play as mechanisms to promote equity for cultural and linguistically diverse children, families, and teachers. Most importantly, she is the mommy of a curious and spunky bilingual toddler — so she is putting her research into practice every day.

Follow her at @cultivating.wonder_ for more advice and information.

In this episode, Veronica answers:

1. Do I have to be fluent in a language to teach my child?

2. What if only one parent is bilingual?

3. It’s hard to have one-sided conversations in a language.

4. Will learning another language delay my child’s speech?

5. Will speaking 2 or 3 languages confuse or overwhelm my child?

#bilingual #multilingual #earlylearning #language #expertadvice

node.text:
Elina Furman is a Certified Infant Massage Instructor with over 15 years in the baby product industry. She is deeply passionate about spreading awareness about the importance of infant/child massage. She earned her certification after talking to many parents who were confused and bewildered about how to perform infant massage. 

By creating an educational platform and a massage enhancement tool, Elina hopes to bridge the gap of knowledge to help parents and underserved families explore this science evidence-based practice performed for thousands of years all over the world.
Follow her at @getkahlmi for more information and tips. 

In this IGTV, Elina answers:

1. What are the benefits of infant massage?

2. How to start and when to do it? How often? And until what age?

3. What if it seems like my baby doesn’t like massage?

4. Does infant massage help babies sleep better?

5. How do we continue with massage for older children?

6. Can massages relieve gas discomfort and can it be done before my baby gets to that point?

7. Are there any massages to help with teething?

#infantmassage #babydevelopment #expertadvice

node.text:
Gopika Kamdar, MA, CCC-SLP is a Licensed Speech-Language Pathologist with a passion for the human brain, early childhood development, and parent coaching.

Her work focuses on how all parts of development play an integral part of speech and language development. Follow her at @speechwithgopika for more advice and information.

In this episode, Gopika answers:

1. What age to worry about common mispronounced letters? (ex. R as W) Should my baby get evaluated professionally? 

2. How can I encourage my 3 year old to expand his short sentences?

3. Will mask-wearing by teachers affect the speech development of my 4 month old at daycare?

4. Does using a pacifier until at least 6 months of age affect speech?

Be sure to watch all 3 IGTV videos in this series to hear all of Gopika's answers to the top questions on speech and language development. ✨

#slp #speech #language #childdevelopment #expertadvice

node.text:
Gopika Kamdar, MA, CCC-SLP is a Licensed Speech-Language Pathologist with a passion for the human brain, early childhood development, and parent coaching.

Her work focuses on how all parts of development play an integral part of speech and language development. Follow her at @speechwithgopika for more advice and information.

In this episode, Gopika answers:

1. Should I be concerned about my two year old having a lisp? What causes them? 
2. When should I be worried about other people not understanding my 2 year old? 
3. When should babies start babbling? Is it concerning if an 8 month old baby doesn’t babble? Tips to encourage babbling?

Be sure to watch all 3 IGTV videos in this series to hear all of Gopika's answers to the top questions on speech and language development. ✨

#slp #speech #language #childdevelopment #expertadvice

node.title: Speech and Language Development: Gopika Kamdar, Part 2

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Lovevery on September 17, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'Tip: Toddlers thrive on routines and predictability Setting expectations for your child allows them to take ownership of their everyday life and plan ahead. LOVEVERY'.

node.text:
Routines provide comfort, stability, and a sense of safety for your toddler. 🙌

Patterns in your toddler’s day are comforting because they help them understand and prepare for what’s going to happen next. They also encourage thinking in more advanced ways. When your toddler learns about order and sequence and can recognize patterns, they build more advanced thought processes like reasoning, judgment, and anticipation. ⁣🧠

Some ways you can incorporate routines: 👇

➡️ Use the Lets Map It Out Routine Cards from the Helper Play Kit for 25 to 27 months. 

Children like to know what's going to happen. Visuals support anticipation and sequencing skills, helping make daily tasks like bedtime a little smoother. Visuals can also show that symbols have meaning and order - this is early literacy. 

➡️ Make the Plan Ahead Weather Board from the Observer Play Kit for 37 to 39 months a staple part of your mornings. 

The Weather Board gives your toddler a hands-on tool with visual cues showing what to expect of daily life, allowing them to gradually take ownership over their everyday life and plan ahead.

➡️ Create daily rituals. 

In the morning, sing songs, open the blinds, make the bed, change clothes. 

Before meals, wash hands, get a water cup, sit at the table,  say something your grateful for or sing a song. 

Before + after play time, select a play space, play some music, choose toys, set up, sing a clean up song. 

At night, take a bath, turn on a sound machine, dim the lights, close the curtains or blinds, read some books, and sing a few songs.

These daily rituals and routines will help your toddler build independence and confidence, all while taking ownership of their everyday life! 🥳

#toddlerdevelopment #toddlerlife #toddlerskills #toddlerlearning #toddlermom #toddlersofinstagram #lovevery

node.text:
We hear it all the time, you love our books because they have real children in them! 

Little ones love seeing real faces in the books they read, but did you know there’s research-backed reasons we include real photography in the stories we tell? 📚

Research from the University of London has found that even before their first birthday, babies are able to learn about the real world indirectly through books that include real photographs. 🤩

By looking at books featuring real experiences and people, your child will begin to associate what they see in the book with what they experience everyday. 👏

Books with real photos are a great way to work on language development with your child. More than just reading the words, read the pictures by talking with your child about what they see in the photos. 🗣

Help your child connect with what they are seeing in the photos to items and experiences in the real world. 🌎 

What Lovevery book does your child ask you to read over and over again? 😅

#lovevery #boardbooks #loveverybooks #childrensbooks #languagedevelopment #literacydevelopment #earlyliteracy #preliteracy #toddlerdevelopment #earlylearning

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Lovevery on September 15, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'Tip: Retelling a negative experience helps toddlers connect the parts of the brain they use for emotion with the parts they use fo reasoning. LOVEVERY.'.

node.text:
Dr. Dan Siegel coined the phrase “name it to tame it” as a way of describing how to help a child calm down. Describing what is happening and how the child might be feeling helps them process their emotions and begin to calm down. 🙌⁣⁣
⁣⁣
When you do this, your toddler sees that you believe the feelings they’re having, even if those feelings are frustrating to you in the moment. ⁣⁣
⁣
Children need reassurance that a range of feelings is normal, and that emotions come and go. It’s knowing how to respond to our emotions that’s so critical, especially as we get older. 👍⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Here’s how you can “name it to tame it”: ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
➡️ Try to accept all of your toddler’s feelings. Even when you don’t accept the behavior. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
An example is: If your toddler really wants something at the store and starts screaming, you can name it to tame it by saying, “I can see that you really want that toy—it looks like it would be so fun to play with, doesn’t it? We’re not going to buy it today, and I can tell that upsets you.” If your toddler calms down a bit, you can move along by offering an opportunity to switch gears: “Should we walk or skip to the car?” or “Would you like to hold hands or link elbows?” 😀⁣⁣
⁣⁣
They may, however, still be mid-tantrum and unable to hear much of what you’re saying. 🤪 In this case, consider saying very little (“I know you’re upset”) while offering a hug if they’re ready for one. Take some deep, intentional breaths, and eventually they MIGHT calm down. And other times, they will absolutely not. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
➡️ Connect to past challenges. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Telling the story back to your toddler later on can be reassuring. By reminding them of their own resilience, you are reassuring your toddler that they worked their way through a tough time and now they’re okay. 👌 Use details to remind them of the experience and don’t shy away from using more complex words like “frustrated”, “disappointed”, and “anxious”. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Retelling a negative experience can feel counterintuitive, but it actually helps toddlers connect the parts of the brain they use for emotion with the parts they use for reasoning.

#lovevery #loveverytoddler #toddleremotions #tantrums

node.text:
This baby is on a mission! 💪🙌

This activity is perfect for your brand new crawler who might need just a little motivation to get moving. 👍

Place an enticing toy a few feet away from them to encourage them to crawl towards it, they may still rely on army crawling or other creative ways to move towards the item -- but eventually they will pull themselves up and crawl on over. ✨

Try placing their favorite stuffed animal, stacked blocks for them to knock over, sensory bags, or other fun items you know they already love. 

Thanks to @twolittlesandalatte for tagging us in this precious baby doll rescue mission! 😉

#crawling #newcrawler #babyonthemove #babydevelopment #babyactivities #grossmotorskills #lovevery

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Lovevery on September 11, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'Fact: Independent play is extremely beneficial for your child's development. LOVEVERY'.

node.text:
Every child is different, but children around the age of two are generally going to need adult supervision, guidance, and help, at least beyond the first few minutes. According to a 2008 study in the Infant & Child Development Journal, two-year-olds have an attention span of about 5-8 minutes. ✨⁠

The goods news is: even at this early age there are ways of teaching your toddler independent play.
⁠
Here are some ideas for supporting independent play: ⬇️⁠
⁠
Consider a daily “work time.” If you begin this practice early, it can function in a similar way to “rest time” when kids start to outgrow naps. During work time, everyone is doing something on their own. This time may not last for more than a few minutes at first but can build up to longer stretches. ⏰⁠
⁠
Create a “yes space.” Spaces where children have just the right amount of playthings, at just the right difficulty and interest for them, and where nothing is unsafe or forbidden, are known as “yes spaces.” Children hear “no” a lot, and giving them a space where they’re encouraged to explore without restrictions builds their attention span and supports independent play. 👏⁠
⁠
Offer fewer choices and rotate toys. The Montessori philosophy of play teaches that when it comes to physical objects, less is more. Providing only a few choices helps children get deeper into play, play for longer periods of time, and form more meaningful bonds. 💫⁠
⁠
Set up stations. Teachers often set up simple stations that kids can rotate between. The key here is “simple.” Try putting only a handful of blocks in a basket, a small collection of natural items in another (leaves, pine cones, rocks), and a scale with objects to weigh in a third. 🙌⁠
⁠
Play less “intrusively.” When we play with our young kids, many of us tend to take charge: it’s human nature and a natural habit. When we practice being loving and helpful supporters of play—rather than directors—we allow children to discover more about themselves and what they can do. 🥳⁠
⁠
Encourage pretend play. The more you reinforce that their pretend play is meaningful and fun, the more you’ll see them start to play pretend on their own. ❤️
⁠
#lovevery #independentplay

node.text:
Parents are generally unaware of how ready young toddlers are to learn about numbers. We hear plenty about how important reading is for young children, but early introductions to math matter just as much. 👍

Neuroscientist, Gillian Starkey, says introducing your toddler to math can happen in the course of your regular day; it doesn’t have to require anything special. There are lots of easy ways to pay attention to the math and numbers that are all around us. The important thing is to use math as consciously as you use language so it becomes a regular, familiar part of your child’s day. ✨

A simple way to introduce math and numbers into your toddler’s day is by counting everything -- from toys, to fruit, even the steps from the car to your front door!

Counting helps familiarize your toddler with the concept that there are number words that go along with quantities. “I’m giving you four little crackers—one, two, three, four.” 🔢

Your toddler might start to do their own “counting” around two years old by reciting number words in order and pointing to objects in an attempt to mimic what you do when you count.

They are not yet making the connection between an actual quantity and the corresponding number word they are saying. Later, around age three or four, they will better understand what’s known as “one-to-one correspondence”—one ball goes with the number one, and two balls can be counted “one, two.”

We love this video from @ReyannaRosario of Hannah playing with the Wooden Counting Box from the Free Spirit Play Kit for 34 to 36 months, a great example of a toddler reciting numbers and beginning to correspond them to an activity. 🙌

#math #teachingmath #learningmath #toddlermath #learningnumbers #toddlerdevelopment #toddlerlearning #toddlerlife

node.text:
Your baby can start learning to drink from an open cup at around 6 months. 🙌⁠
⁠
We know—giving a 6-month-old baby an open drinking cup might seem like a crazy idea, but there are many reasons why open cups are a better choice over sippy cups. Babies who have practiced this early can sometimes do away with bottles by 12 months! 🥳⁠
⁠
Speech pathologists and dentists prefer babies to use open cups when possible because open cups help babies build the muscles in their mouths that are used to form sounds (and also lessen drooling). 🤪⁠
⁠
Practice with an open cup helps your baby learn what to do with a small amount of liquid when it reaches their mouth when they’re not sucking on a breast or bottle. 👏⁠
⁠
Here’s how to get started:⁠ 👇
⁠
Consider introducing the open cup during seated mealtimes, once they’re eating finger foods. 😋 ⁠
⁠
Start with a small amount of water, no more than an inch, and first model drinking from the cup for your baby. 💦⁠
⁠
At first, your baby may just pour the water out, bang the cup on the table, or drop the cup on the floor—they’re learning about pouring, real-life cause and effect, containment, and gravity. Good thing it’s just water! 😛⁠
⁠
Over the next few months, your baby will start to understand how to tilt the cup and drink the water that ends up in their mouth. 😍⁠
⁠
At this age, your baby should have no more than one to two ounces of water per day — breastmilk/formula should be their primary source of nutrition. ✨⁠
⁠
Straw cups use different muscles than an open cup and are preferred over sippy cups. A good balance would be to use a straw cup when on the go or concerned about spilling, and an open cup during seated mealtimes. 💪⁠

#babydevelopment #physicaldevelopment #lovevery

node.text:
Teamwork makes the dream work! 🥳

Teaching our children to share is often an early goal for us parents, but adults often ask children to share long before they are ready. 

For children, the whole idea of sharing feels arbitrary: what are the rules? Why do we take turns with certain objects and not others? Why do we have to do this at all? It’s not hard to see why sharing is a hard sell with small children 🙃⁠
⁠
When we talk about sharing with toddlers, what we’re really talking about is turn-taking. Taking turns involves waiting while someone else uses the exact object you want to use, and it’s hard for anyone, really. Children may be cognitively and developmentally ready to start taking turns at around age two. Even then, they will almost always need to be supported and guided by an adult. ⁠
⁠
Sharing, on the other hand, is a complex collaborative process involving a common goal, and comes later, beginning around age four. ⁠
⁠
Here are some tips for helping your little one learn to take turns 👇:⁠
⁠
Before playing with other children, put away a small number of special “non-negotiables,” like favorite or special items. ⁠
⁠
Preview what’s going to happen so it's not a surprise: "you're playing with the truck now, and in three minutes it's going to be Maria's turn, and she will get to play with it for awhile." 🙌⁠
⁠
Use a visual timer to help your child know when their turn is up. ⁠
⁠
Practice turn-taking in everyday life, like making a smoothie together and take turns dropping banana slices in one by one or doing a puzzle together and taking turns adding the pieces. 💕⁠

Twins might learn to share and take turns more quickly since they are used to having another child around the same age as them who is also interested in similar things. ✨

#toddlerdevelopment #toddlerskills #toddleractivities #toddlerlife #toddlertips #turntaking #sharingiscaring #lovevery #woodentoys #sustainabletoys

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Lovevery on September 07, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'These four fun sensory activities help build your toddler's neural pathways.'.

node.text:
Sensory activities engage the body and mind in a way that builds critical neural pathways: children do something, and the environment around them reacts, forming new connections and associations. We all need feedback to grow and thrive, and this is particularly true of young children. ✨

Here are four sensory activities for your toddler or older child: 👇

🧼 Shaving Cream Play 

Shaving cream is inexpensive and so fun to squish through your fingers, which is why it’s a favorite sensory play ingredient. On a hot day, give your child a can of shaving cream and a hose with the water set to mist or fine spray, and let them play. They can be naked or in a swimsuit, and this is best done on a hard surface (a driveway, sidewalk, brick, or stone).

🎨 Painting with Frozen Paint

You can freeze washable paint (add a little water). A popsicle stick or toothpick make the perfect paintbrush. To get the “handles” to stay put, you can either wait until the paint is partially frozen, or cover the tray with plastic wrap or aluminum foil and poke the sticks through. Once they’re frozen, let them melt for a few minutes (this makes them easier to paint with) and give your child a large piece of paper and let them paint. They’ll enjoy how the texture changes and the colors mix as the paint cubes begin to melt.

🦶Painting with Feet

Lay out paper flat on the ground, and tape or weight the ends down with heavy objects. Dot the paper with washable paint. Use a variety of colors, but don’t use too much paint—small dollops, spaced a few inches apart, should do the trick. Invite your child to paint! If they need a little encouragement to use their feet, invite your child to try a finger first. They can explore how the paint moves and feels with a finger before trying their feet.

🧊Ice Cube and Salt Towers

At 31 months, many children can start building block towers in more complex ways, including making a bridge with three blocks and a tower with eight. As a fun twist, try it with ice cubes on a tray—their cold, slippery properties make them difficult to balance, but dipping an ice cube in salt (then waiting a few moments) before adding it to the tower helps it all stick together.

node.text:
"If I’m being honest I was a bit skeptical about the high contrast cards before Yitzchak was born. I kind of thought they were created as a way to sell a toy for newborns and that while, yes, the fact that they are images that babies can see is backed by science, they wouldn’t really grab the baby’s attention. Boy was I wrong. 

Yitzchak loves his black and white cards. He can stare at them for far longer than I can focus on any one thing. They even calm him when he is upset. Once again I am reminded just how much we underestimate babies. 

Concentration is so much more natural than I realized before. While I am giving him opportunities to develop this concentration through his black and white cards and mobiles, I also feel all the more sure of my decision to avoid toys that light up or make noise. His concentration is incredible and I don’t want to undermine that. 

Babies really are so much more capable than we give them credit for and he shows me this every day." - @homeandontheway 💕
